Scheme 1 Reaction route from 2,3-BDO to BD via 3B2OL. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Proposed mechanism in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to BD through 3B2OL over Sc3+ and O2− ions exposed on the oxygen defect site of Sc2O3 shown in Fig. 12f. Some of O2− and Sc3+ ions in Fig. 12f were removed for clarity. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 XRD profiles of HT-Sc2O3 (a) and PC-Sc2O3 (b) samples calcined at different temperatures. Fig 1 Fig. 2 FE-SEM images of HT-Sc2O3 (a, b, c) and PC-Sc2O3 (d, e). As-prepared Sc2O3 (a, d); Sc2O3 calcined at 800 °C (b, e) and 1000 °C (c). A scale bar in the SEM images indicates 100 nm. Fig 2 Fig. 3 TG profiles of as-prepared ScOOH via HT aging for 0 (a), 4 (b), and 24 h (c) and HT-Sc2O3–400 (d). Fig 3 Fig. 4 TPD profiles of adsorbed NH3 (red) and CO2 (blue) on HT-Sc2O3 calcined at 600 (a) and 800 °C (b) together with PC-Sc2O3 calcined at 800 °C (c). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig 4 Fig. 5 Effect of calcination temperature of HT-Sc2O3 (a) and PC-Sc2O3 (b) on the catalytic activity and effect of specific surface area of Sc2O3 (c). Dehydration of 2,3-butanediol to produce 1,3-butadiene over Sc2O3 catalyst prepared through hydrothermal aging Kazuki Nakazono Conceptualization Data curation Visualization Writing – original draft a Ryoji Takahashi Data curation Writing – review & editing b Yasuhiro Yamada Supervision Validation a Satoshi Sato Project administration Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Yayoi, Inage, Chiba 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering Chiba University Yayoi, Inage Chiba 263-8522 Japan aGraduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Yayoi, Inage, Chiba 263-8522, Japan b Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Ehime University, 2-5 Bunkyocho, Matsuyama, Ehime 790-8577, Japan Graduate School of Science and Engineering Ehime University 2-5 Bunkyocho Matsuyama Ehime 790-8577 Japan bGraduate School of Science and Engineering, Ehime University, 2-5 Bunkyocho, Matsuyama, Ehime 790-8577, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Vapor-phase catalytic dehydration of 2,3-butanediol (2,3-BDO) to form 1,3-butadiene (BD) via 3-buten-2-ol (3B2OL) was studied over various single metal oxide catalysts. Among the catalysts, Sc2O3 prepared under hydrothermal (HT) conditions at 200 °C followed by 800 °C calcination showed the most excellent catalytic activity. The crystallization of precursor ScOOH during HT aging noticeably enhances the catalytic activity of the resulting Sc2O3 for the formation of 3B2OL in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO. The formation rate of 3B2OL from 2,3-BDO over the HT-aged Sc2O3 was twice as high as Sc2O3 without HT aging. Calcination temperatures of Sc2O3 are also important: calcination at 800 °C is efficient for the selective formation of 3B2OL from 2,3-BDO. The HT-aged Sc2O3 also showed an excellent catalytic activity for the formation of BD with the yield higher than 80% in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO at 411 °C. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dehydration of 2,3-butanediol 1,3-butadiene Unsaturated alcohol Hydrothermally aged Sc2O3 Cubic bixbyite with high crystallinity 1 Introduction In the petrochemical industry, transform of raw materials from oil to carbon-neutral renewable resources such as biomass has been required due to global warming. Butanediols (BDOs) such as 2,3-butanediol (2,3-BDO) [1–7], 1,4-BDO [2–5], and 1,3-BDO [5] are derivable from biomass via metabolic conversion of carbohydrates. The formation of 2,3-BDO was studied for the production of 1,3-butadiene (BD) as a strategic compound for the synthetic rubber during the World War II [1,8]. In 2019, the number of reports on the metabolic formation of 2,3-BDO is about three hundred, which is much larger than those of the other BDOs [9]. Recently, chemical production of 2,3-BDO from biomass-derived chemicals is reported in the hydrogenation of 3-hydroxy-2-butanone (acetoin) and 2,3-butanedione (diacetyl) [10] and the photoreductive dimerization of ethanol [11]. The bio-based 2,3-BDO can be utilized as a chemical raw material for the production of variable chemicals such as BD, 3-buten-2-ol (3B2OL), butanone (MEK), butene isomers, and so on [12,13]. In 1945, it was reported that a radioactive ThO2 showed a catalytic activity for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to form 3B2OL, which can be further dehydrated into BD [8]. Sc2O3 catalyst has recently been found to exhibit high selectivity to BD in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO through 3B2OL [14]. γ-Al2O3 has catalytic activity in the vapor-phase dehydration of 2,3-BDO to form BD and MEK [15–17]: γ-Al2O3 produces MEK preferentially at high conversions and BD increases with increasing the reaction temperature [17]. Acidic catalysts with Brønsted acid sites such as boron-modified HZSM-5 [18] and aluminum phosphate [19] effectively convert 2,3-BDO into MEK along with 2-methylpropanal (MPA) led by pinacol rearrangement. In contrast, weakly acidic SiO2-supported phosphates [20–22] and unsupported phosphates [23–26] are reported to be effective for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to form BD together with MEK. We have previously reported that 2,3-BDO can be preferentially dehydrated to 3B2OL over Sc2O3 [14,27], In2O3 [27], and modified ZrO2 catalysts [28,29] at 300 °C or higher. Since 3B2OL is a significant intermediate to form BD from 2,3-BDO, the selective formation of 3B2OL from 2,3-BDO is a crucial step to improve the selectivity to BD (Scheme 1 ). The reactivity of BDOs, which depends on the catalyst, varies with the position of OH groups of BDOs. An yttria-stabilized zirconia shows an excellent stable catalytic activity for the dehydration of 1,3- and 1,4-BDO, but the addition of Y into ZrO2 decreases the selectivity to 3B2OL in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO [30]. In the rare earth oxides, Sc2O3 has moderate catalytic activity in the dehydration of 1,3-and 1,4-BDO, in which Lu2O3 and Yb2O3 are more active than Sc2O3 [12]. As far as we know, however, Sc2O3 has the highest activity for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to form 3B2OL with high selectivity [9,27]. Sc2O3 is also active for the dehydration of long-chain terminal diols such as 1,6-hexanediol and 1,ω-alkanediols (ω= 7, 8, 9, 10, and 12) [31]. In2O3, which has the same crystal structure of cubic bixbyite Sc2O3, shows the second-highest selectivity to 3B2OL in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO [27], while In2O3 is also active for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO, 1,4-BDO, and 1,5-pentanediol [32,33]. Recently, we have reported an excellent Yb2Zr2O7 catalyst for the vapor-phase dehydration of 1,3-BDO to produce unsaturated alcohols [34]. A Yb2Zr2O7 prepared through hydrothermal (HT) aging is more active than the precipitated samples without HT aging. The specific surface areas of Yb2Zr2O7 are as high as 40 m2 g−1 even after being calcined at a temperature of 800 °C, in contrast to the fact that the precipitated catalysts without HT aging are readily sintered at the temperature. Also, Y2Zr2O7 prepared through HT aging efficiently catalyzed the formation of BD from 1,3-BDO at 360 °C [35]. In addition, HT-aged Er2O3 shows excellent catalytic activity in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to form 3-buten-1-ol [36]. It should be noticed that Lu2O3, Yb2O3, and Er2O3, which show high selectivity to unsaturated alcohols in the dehydration of 1,3- and 1,4-BDOs, have the same cubic crystalline structure of bixbyite Sc2O3 [37,38]. We expect that such an HT aging of a hydroxide precipitate precursor could enhance the crystallinity of the resulting oxide with improved catalytic activity. Therefore, in this study, we firstly focused on the efficient production of 3B2OL from 2,3-BDO over various HT-aged oxide samples. In the preliminary catalyst screening, we selected Sc2O3 as a candidate catalyst in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to produce 3B2OL. In addition, the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to efficiently form BD was investigated over the HT-aged Sc2O3 catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples Scandium(III) nitrate, Sc(NO3)3·nH2O (n = 5, which was determined by weight loss in thermogravimetry (TG) analysis) and other nitrates such as Y(NO3)3·6H2O, Dy(NO3)3·nH2O, Yb(NO3)3·6H2O, were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. In(NO3)3·3H2O, ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O, and an internal standard of 1-hexanol were purchased from Wako Pure Chemicals Industries, Ltd. A commercial Sc2O3 as a reference catalyst was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co., Ltd., which is named CM-Sc2O3. Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-6) was supplied by the Reference Catalyst Division, the Catalysis Society of Japan. SiO2 (CARiACT Q10 with mean pore diameters of 10 nm) was supplied by Fuji Silycia Chemical Ltd. A reactant 2,3-BDO was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry, Co., Ltd. It was used for the catalytic reaction without any further purification. Sc2O3 was prepared through an HT aging of a precipitate prepared as follows. In a typical preparation, 5.00 g of Sc(NO3)3·5H2O was dissolved in 50 cm3 of distilled water, and the pH of the solution was adjusted to 9.8 with 25 wt.% aqueous ammonia under stirring to form a hydroxide precipitate. The solution together with the precipitate was heated in a 100 cm3 Teflon-lined autoclave at 200 °C for 24 h. The recovered precipitate was centrifuged, washed with distilled water three times, dried at 110 °C for 24 h, and finally calcined at the prescribed temperature for 3 h. The resulting Sc2O3 is denoted as HT-Sc2O3. The other Sc2O3 catalyst was prepared by a precipitation method in the same way as the procedure described above without HT aging, and the resulting Sc2O3 was expressed as PC-Sc2O3. The sample name was also denoted, including the calcination temperature, T (°C), as Sc2O3-T. The other oxide samples were prepared in the same manner as the preparation of Sc2O3 using the corresponding nitrate. In the preparation of rare earth zirconate catalysts (REZrO), such as Sc2O3-ZrO2 (ScZrO), Yb2O3-ZrO2 (YbZrO), and Lu2O3-ZrO2 (LuZrO), the corresponding nitrates were used in a similar manner to that of Sc2O3, which was described in a previous paper [39]. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was recorded on New D8 ADVANCE (Bruker) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) to identify the crystal phase of each sample. A crystallite size, D XRD , of Sc2O3 sample was estimated by calculating from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) by Scherrer equation: D XRD = Kλ/(βcosθ), where K (= 0.9), λ, β, and θ are shape factor, X-ray wavelength, FWHM, and Bragg's diffraction angle, respectively. A particle size, D BET, of Sc2O3 was calculated by the following equation, D BET = 6/d/SA, assuming that the particles are spherical where d and SA are the density of Sc2O3 (d = 3.864 g cm−3 [40]) and the specific surface area, respectively. To characterize the crystal structure of rare earth oxides such as Sc2O3, Yb2O3, Y2O3, and Dy2O3, including In2O3, crystal structure modeling was performed using VESTA 3 software [41] with the National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS) AtomWork Database [42] including crystallographic data of Sc2O3 [43], Yb2O3, Y2O3, Dy2O3 [44], and In2O3 [45]. A structure of reactant meso-2,3-BDO with a gauche-type configuration was optimized with Gaussian 16 (B3LYP/6–31 g(d) integral = grid = ultrafine) [46] to determine the distances between reactive atoms of the optimized model meso-2,3-BDO. In the optimized model of meso-2,3-BDO, which is displayed in Fig. S1, the O-O distance between the OH groups, the O-H distance between the position-1 hydrogen and the position-2 OH group, and the other O-H distance between the position-1 hydrogen and the position-3 OH group were determined to be 2.95, 2.69, and 2.47 Å, respectively. The other methods for characterization on N2 adsorption for calculation of SA, high-resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) image, TG, and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of adsorbed NH3 and CO2 were described in the supplementary information (SI) file. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The vapor-phase catalytic dehydration of 2,3-BDO was performed in a fixed-bed flow reactor at atmospheric pressure. After a catalyst (typically catalyst weight, W = 0.5 g) had been heated at the prescribed reaction temperature for 1 h, 2,3-BDO was fed into the reactor at a feed rate, F, of 1.60 g h−1, and continued for time on stream (TOS) of typically 5 h. Unless otherwise described, N2 was flowed as a carrier gas at a rate of 1.8 dm3 h−1. The details of the procedure were described in SI file. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Dehydration of 2,3-BDO over various catalysts We have previously reported that a commercial Sc2O3 (purchased from KANTOCHEMICAL CO., INC.) with an SA of 51.5 m2 g−1, which was prepared by decomposing the corresponding chlorides at temperatures above 2000 °C for ca. 2 s in the vapor phase [37], achieved a BD yield of 67% in N2 and 88% in H2 at 411 °C and a space time, W/F, of 0.94 h [14]. However, the excellent results have not been reproduced by the other commercial ones: Zeng et al. reported that CM-Sc2O3 achieved the BD selectivity of about 30% at 411 °C and a W/F = 0.93 h [47]. We also obtained a similar poor result over CM-Sc2O3 obtained from the same supplier, as described in Section 3.6 of this study. Therefore, we have to establish a method for preparing an active Sc2O3 catalyst. Thus, we adopted a method of HT aging of the hydroxide precursor in this study to obtain catalysts with high crystallinity. In the beginning, we screened various candidate oxide catalysts prepared through HT aging. Table 1 shows the conversion of 2,3-BDO over metal oxide catalysts prepared via HT aging at 200 °C for 24 h under the reaction conditions in N2 flow at 325 °C and a W/F= 0.31 h. Over a SiO2, the conversion of 2,3-BDO was zero. This indicates that no catalytic dehydration of 2,3-BDO proceeds in a blank test without catalysts. Over a reference Al2O3, the conversion of 2,3-BDO was relatively high; the primary product was MEK together with by-products such as ethanol, 2-butanol, 2-methyl-1-propanol, and MPA at 250 °C. It is known that 2,3-BDO converts into MEK along with MPA through pinacol rearrangement over acidic catalysts such as Al2O3 [15–17], B-modified HZSM-5 [18], and aluminum phosphate [19]. In contrast, over rare earth oxide catalysts such as Yb2O3, Y2O3, and Dy2O3, the conversion levels of 2,3-BDO were low even at 325 °C and 2,3-BDO competitively converted to form 3B2OL and acetoin, suggesting that the catalysts also promote the dehydrogenation of 2,3-BDO in addition to the dehydration. In addition, ZrO2 was as active as the rare earth oxides, as reported previously [15]. REZrO catalysts, which are recently reported to be active in the dehydration of 1,3- and 1,4-BDO [39], were also active in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO with the 3B2OL selectivity of ca. 50% at the 2,3-BDO conversions less than 20%, while REZrO showed higher 2,3-BDO conversions and higher 3B2OL selectivity than rare earth oxides such as Yb2O3 and Y2O3. However, the 3B2OL selectivity of the HT-aged samples is unfortunately unsatisfied. Sc2O3 catalysts showed high activity to produce 3B2OL with high selectivity in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO at 325 °C. In particular, HT-Sc2O3 attained the highest 3B2OL selectivity of 95.1% at the 2,3-BDO conversion of 68.8%. Thus, HT-Sc2O3 was more active than PC-Sc2O3 without HT aging and CM-Sc2O3. The activity of PC-Sc2O3 was comparable to that of CM-Sc2O3, in which the selectivity to 3B2OL was 90.0% at the 2,3-BDO conversion of 25.3%. We have previously tested the same CM-Sc2O3 under different conditions [27]: the selectivity to 3B2OL is 88.2% at the 2,3-BDO conversion of 96.5% at a high W/F of 0.94 h. It is reasonable that the present conversion level of CM-Sc2O3 is low at a low W/F of 0.31 h. HT-In2O3 also had a high dehydration ability to 3B2OL, but the 3B2OL selectivity was ca. 75%. In2O3, which has the same crystal structure of bixbyite Sc2O3, is known as an effective catalyst for the dehydration of 1,4-BDO to 3-buten-1-ol [32,33]. The SA values of HT-In2O3 samples were as low as 6–18 m2 g−1. Calcination at 800 °C or higher enhanced the catalytic activity of In2O3. HT-In2O3–900 showed the highest 2,3-BDO conversion and high 3B2OL selectivity, irrespective of low SA. The conversion and selectivity levels of HT-In2O3–900 are higher than those of a commercially available In2O3 reported in a previous work [27]. 3.2 Structural property of HT-Sc2O3 catalysts Fig. 1 shows continuous scanning XRD analysis of HT- and PC-Sc2O3 samples calcined at different temperatures. As-prepared samples are the resulting precipitate dried at 110 °C for 24 h without calcination. The as-prepared sample of HT series, as well as the samples heated at 200 ad 300 °C, was composed of orthorhombic ScOOH (PDF 00–017–0941, Amcm, No.63). The peak intensity did not change by heating at 300 °C or lower. This suggests that crystal growth well proceeds during HT aging. The as-prepared sample of PC series was also composed of orthorhombic ScOOH. However, the diffraction peaks of the as-prepared PC samples were broad indicating the presence of amorphous scandium oxyhydroxides and/or not enough growth of ScOOH. It is reasonable that the crystallites of ScOOH as primary particles are grown during HT aging. Calcination at 400 °C or higher changes the crystal phase from ScOOH to cubic bixbyite Sc2O3 (PDF 01–074–1210, Ia-3, No.206) in both HT and PC samples. The diffraction peaks of bixbyite Sc2O3 became stronger and sharper with raising the calcination temperature. On the other hand, the diffraction peaks of HT samples are sharper and stronger than those of PC samples at the same calcination temperature. This means that the crystallite size of HT catalysts is larger than PC ones at the same calcination conditions. Table 2 summarizes the SA of HT- and PC-Sc2O3 catalysts calcined at different temperatures together with the particle size, D BET and crystallite size, D XRD. The SA of as-prepared HT-Sc2O3 was 58.5 m2 g−1. The SA of HT-Sc2O3 decreased gradually from 58.3 to 15.8 m2 g−1 with increasing the calcination temperature from 400 to 1000 °C. In the HT-Sc2O3, particle size, D BET, and crystallite size, D XRD, well coincide each other at all calcination temperatures. This suggests that HT-Sc2O3 samples consist of well-grown crystallites which exist as primally particles. It should be noted, however, that D XRD calculated from FWHM of diffraction peaks underestimates the crystallite size when the peaks become sharp because of the broadening of incident beam. In the PC-Sc2O3, while the SA of as-prepared sample was 76.3 m2 g−1 and the SA of PC-Sc2O3 increased rapidly to 148.4 m2 g−1 at a calcination of 400 °C. Because there are no large ScOOH crystallites observed in the as-prepared PC-Sc2O3 as shown in XRD pattern, this change can be attributed to the crystallization of amorphous scandium oxyhydroxides rather than the decomposition of a large ScOOH particle into small Sc2O3 crystallites. An increase in the SA observed at 400 °C is attributed to the transition from amorphous scandium oxyhydroxides to Sc2O3. A similar change in SA has been reported in an alumina sample with the transition from Al(OH)3 to Al2O3 [48], where the SA of as-prepared Al(OH)3 was as small as 40 m2 g−1 but increased to 450 m2 g−1 after calcination at 300 °C. The SA of PC-Sc2O3 decreased rapidly from 148.4 to 29.9 m2 g−1 from 400 to 800 °C. During the significant decrease in SA upon calcination, a change in crystallite size is not so large compared to the change in D BET. Therefore, the decrease in SA can be attributed to the aggregation of primally crystallites rather than the crystal growth. In contrast, there observed negligible change in SA in HT samples after calcination at 400 °C irrespective of the occurrence of complete crystal phase change. This suggests that the phase change does not affect the morphology of crystallites in the HT-Sc2O3 samples. Although both HT- and PC-Sc2O3–800 have the same crystal structure, bixbyite Sc2O3, they show different change in the relation between SA and D XRD upon calcination. In order to clarify the reason, we adopted FE-SEM observation. Fig. 2 shows FE-SEM images of several Sc2O3 samples to confirm the morphology of Sc2O3. As-prepared HT sample consists with square-shape thick plates with the size of ca. 50 nm. It is reasonable to grow in plate-shape morphology in orthorhombic ScOOH under HT aging because it has layered structures. In the HT-Sc2O3–800 sample, rounded square plates whose size are similar to those observed in as-aged HT sample remain and they are a main component of the samples. The particle size observed in SEM agrees well with the values of D XRD and D BET (Table 2) so that each particle observed in HT-Sc2O3–800 was composed of single crystallites. That is, ScOOH crystallite grown under HT aging changes to Sc2O3 without the change in morphology. Besides, the fusion of crystallites proceeded when samples were calcined at 900 °C or higher, and then the crystallite size was different from the particle size. On the other hand, the as-prepared PC sample seems to be aggregates of small particles. Most of them would be amorphous scandium oxyhydroxides. In the PC-Sc2O3–800, the sample seems to be a sintered body rather than the aggregates of particles. The size of spherical particles with the plane structure composed the sintered body was 20–30 nm, which agrees with only D XRD but not with D BET (Table 2) because of sintering. The surface of the PC-Sc2O3 sample was flat, and holes were scarcely formed; therefore, the SA decreased, and the crystallite size did not agree with the particle size. It is confirmed that the HT aging of hydroxide precursor results in the growth of ScOOH crystallites and the control of crystallo-morphology of calcined Sc2O3. In our previous report, the morphology of Er2O3 is controlled by HT aging [36]. Er2O3 crystal prepared by HT aging becomes a nanorod structure, while Er2O3 crystals are generally spheres or octahedrons and are called nanoparticles. Table 3 summarizes the SA of the Sc2O3 catalysts prepared at different HT aging periods. The SA of the resulting Sc2O3–800 samples was slightly decreased with extending HT aging time from 4 h. Fig. S2 shows the XRD patterns of the Sc2O3 catalysts prepared in different HT aging periods. Although the patterns of the Sc2O3–800 samples were similar to each other, the peak intensity of the as-prepared samples was increased with extending HT aging time. The D BET and D XRD values slightly increased with extending HT aging time (Table S1), suggesting that the crystallites of ScOOH grew by HT aging and maintained the morphology with high crystallinity after the calcination at 800 °C. The SA of Sc2O3 after calcination was related to that of as-prepared, suggesting that the SA of Sc2O3 decreased with extending HT aging time due to the growth of crystallites. The D BET of PC-Sc2O3 at HT time of 0 h was the largest, and the D BET of HT-Sc2O3 increased as the HT aging time extended. Although sintering of PC-Sc2O3 between primary particles progresses together with the crystallization during the calcination at 800 °C, HT-Sc2O3 showed the growth of ScOOH crystallites during HT aging. This indicates that the large crystallites suppress the sintering between primary particles during calcination. Fig. 3 shows TG profiles of as-prepared ScOOH with different HT aging periods. In the HT samples, the decrease in weight at temperatures below 400 °C is smaller than that of the PC sample at HT time of 0 h. This suggests that HT aging converts amorphous scandium oxyhydroxides into ScOOH single phase and allows growth of ScOOH into plate-like shape, and that amorphous scandium oxyhydroxides in PC sample lose their excess H2O during heating up to 400 °C. It is confirmed that the HT aging promotes crystallization and suppresses the sintering between particles during calcination. Consequently, Sc2O3 with high crystallinity was successfully prepared without a significant decrease in SA even after calcination at 800 °C. 3.3 Acid-base property of Sc2O3 catalysts Fig. 4 shows temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) profiles of CO2 and NH3 adsorbed on HT-Sc2O3–600, HT-Sc2O3–800, and PC-Sc2O3–800 catalysts, where original data are displayed in Fig. S3. Strength distributions of acid and base sites were similar to each other in each Sc2O3 sample. In HT samples, the amounts of acid and base sites decrease with raising the calcination temperature and decreasing the SA. In Fig. 4a, the amount of NH3 desorbed from HT-Sc2O3–600 is larger than the amount of CO2. The amounts of acid and base sites were calculated to be 0.156 and 0.136 mmol g−1 from the profiles up to the desorption temperature of 600 °C, respectively. On the other hand, the amounts of acid and base sites of HT-Sc2O3–800 are very similar (Fig. 4b): the amounts of acid and base sites were calculated to be 0.070 and 0.068 mmol g−1, respectively. Since the adsorption of NH3 and CO2 has been observed at temperatures above 325 °C, the acid and base sites could be poisoned by the probes of NH3 and CO2 during the reaction at 325 °C, respectively. In PC-Sc2O3–800, the amounts of acid and base sites were calculated to be 0.062 and 0.048 mmol g−1, respectively (Fig. 4c). The amounts of acid and base sites were higher in HT-Sc2O3–800 than those of PC-Sc2O3–800. The densities of acid and base sites calculated by dividing the amounts of acid and base sites by the SA were 2.10 and 2.05 μmol m−2 for HT-Sc2O3–800 and 2.06 and 1.60 μmol m−2 for PC-Sc2O3–800, respectively. HT-Sc2O3 could have a higher density of acid and base sites than PC-Sc2O3 due to its high crystallinity leading to better acid-base balance compared to PC-Sc2O3 with rough surfaces. On the other hand, the densities of acid and base sites of HT-Sc2O3–600 were 2.97 and 2.59 μmol m−2, respectively, which are higher than those of HT-Sc2O3–800. Since HT-Sc2O3–800 was more favorable for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to 3B2OL than HT-Sc2O3–600 (Fig. 5 ), the catalytic activity cannot be explained by only the amount and the density of the acid and base sites. This issue is discussed in the following section related to the reaction mechanism on a specific adsorption site. 3.4 Dehydration of 2,3-BDO to form 3B2OL over HT-Sc2O3 catalysts Fig. 5 shows the effect of calcination temperature of HT- and PC-Sc2O3 catalyst on the SA and the conversion of 2,3-BDO at 325 °C and a W/F of 0.31 h, where the numerical data are summarized in Table S2. The conversion of 2,3-BDO and the selectivity to 3B2OL increased with raising the calcination temperature irrespective of the decrease in the SA. HT-Sc2O3–800 showed the highest 2,3-BDO conversion as well as the highest 3B2OL selectivity (Fig. 5a). Although the 3B2OL selectivity was high over HT-Sc2O3 calcined at 900 °C or higher, the 2,3-BDO conversion decreased, owing to the decrease in the SA. Similarly, in PC-Sc2O3 samples, the 2,3-BDO conversion and the 3B2OL selectivity increased with raising the calcination temperature, regardless of the decrease in SA (Fig. 5b). On the other hand, the highest 2,3-BDO conversion and 3B2OL selectivity were observed for PC-Sc2O3–700. HT-Sc2O3 showed higher 3B2OL selectivity than PC-Sc2O3 at all calcination temperatures (Fig. 5c). Similarly, the effect of calcination temperature on the 2,3-BDO conversion has also been observed in the other commercially available Sc2O3 catalyst [27]. It is indicated that the calcination at high temperatures induces the growth of well-crystallized Sc2O3 particles and the construction of effective surfaces for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to 3B2OL. To investigate the effect of HT aging time, we conducted activity tests using Sc2O3 prepared in different aging periods (Table 3). As the HT aging time extended, the 3B2OL selectivity increased, and the conversion decreased. At a long aging time of 72 h, on the other hand, the 3B2OL selectivity decreased. However, both the conversion and the 3B2OL selectivity were higher than those of PC-Sc2O3 with the aging time of 0 h. As shown in Table S1, the D XRD increases with extending the HT aging time, suggesting that the crystallites grew during the HT aging, and the high crystallinity was maintained after calcination. As a result, the HT-aged catalysts showed high 3B2OL selectivity. As the HT aging time extended, the SA of HT-Sc2O3–800 decreased. The longer the HT aging time, the smaller the SA becomes due to the growth of crystallites. Thus, the shorter HT aging time results in a larger SA and thus provided a higher conversion. We performed catalytic reactions over HT-Sc2O3–800 at a constant W/F = 0.31 h and different temperatures (Fig. 6 and Table S3). The 2,3-BDO conversion increased with increasing the reaction temperature, and the complete conversion was attained at 375 °C or higher. The 3B2OL selectivity decreased with increasing the temperature through a maximum of 325 °C, while the selectivity to BD, MEK, and ethanol increased. It is suggested that high temperatures promote the consecutive dehydration and the decomposition of 3B2OL. At temperatures of 375 and 400 °C, the MEK selectivity was higher than 350 and 411 °C. Fig. S4 shows the changes in catalytic activity with TOS at 350, 375, 400, and 411 °C. The MEK selectivity increased with TOS, and the BD selectivity decreased at 375 and 400 °C, and the 3B2OL selectivity also decreased with TOS at 400 °C. It has been reported that the dehydration of MEK to BD does not proceed in the reaction of MEK at 425 °C over Sc2O3 catalyst [14], and thus MEK is not an intermediate to BD at temperatures of 425 °C and lower. These results suggest that the active sites for the formation of 3B2OL and BD deactivate with TOS and that the MEK formation proceeds at different active sites, which could increase the MEK selectivity. At a reaction temperature of 411 °C, the MEK selectivity was stable and remained low during the initial 5 h; at 425 °C or higher, the MEK selectivity increased with TOS, suggesting that a reaction temperature lower than 425 °C is preferable for the selective formation of BD. At a reaction temperature of 475 °C, the BD selectivity decreased in favor of the MEK formation. Fig. 7 shows the effect of space time, W/F, on the 2,3-BDO conversion and the 3B2OL selectivity over HT-Sc2O3–800 at 325 °C, where the numerical data are listed in Table S4. The space time, W/F, was controlled by the variation of W at a constant F. The 2,3-BDO conversion increased with increasing the space time. At a W/F = 0.94 h, the 2,3-BDO conversion of 98.7% was attained with the highest 3B2OL yield of 81.9%. However, the 3B2OL selectivity was decreased with a further increase in the space time, and the selectivity to MEK, BD, and ethanol increased. Thus, the high space time at 325 °C would induce the sequential dehydration and the decomposition of 3B2OL. Fig. 8 shows the changes in the 2,3-BDO conversion and the 3B2OL selectivity with TOS in the extended run test over HT-Sc2O3–800 at 325 °C and a W/F = 0.31 h. Both the 2,3-BDO conversion and the 3B2OL selectivity were gradually decreased in an N2 flow all through the run of 30 h. In an H2 carrier gas, the 2,3-BDO conversion was relatively stable, whereas the decrease in the conversion for the initial 10 h. In the H2 flow, the 3B2OL selectivity was maintained at a high level of 90% for 30 h. Although the 2,3-BDO conversion in H2 flow was lower than that in N2 flow in the initial reaction period, that in H2 flow became higher than that in N2 flow at TOS longer than 15 h. An H2 carrier gas sometimes accelerates the formation rate, and sometimes depressed it. It has been reported in the literature that the acceleration by H2 in the formation of unsaturated alcohols (UOLs) in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO over Y2Zr2O7 [39] and CaO-modified ZrO2 (CaO/ZrO2) [49]. In contrast, the formation rate of UOLs is depressed in H2 flow in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO over Er2O3 and CeO2 [50]. Besides, in the formation of BD from 2,3-BDO over Sc2O3 [14], H2 accelerates the formation. In Fig. 8, however, H2 depressed the initial catalytic activity of Sc2O3 in the formation of 3B2OL from 2,3-BDO, but it decreased the depression rate resulting in the stable catalytic activity in a long run compared to N2 carrier gas. It is not easy to explain the effect of H2 carrier gas, because the effect of H2 carrier gas depends on the types of reactants and catalysts. 3.5 Effect of carrier gas on the dehydration of 2,3-BDO over HT-Sc2O3 catalysts In our previous report, a poisoning experiment using NH3 and CO2 carrier gas is performed in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO over CaO/ZrO2 [28]: the formation of 3B2OL decreased in both gases. The poisoning results indicate that the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to 3B2OL is catalyzed by acid and base sites of the CaO/ZrO2 via a base-acid concerted mechanism. Furthermore, it should be noticed that the dehydration of 2,3-BDO also proceeds over strong acidic alumina and zeolites, and the stepwise dehydration of 3B2OL to BD was promoted by the acid sites in addition to the formation of 3B2OL [15,18]. The TPD profiles displayed in Fig. 4 show that NH3 and CO2 are adsorbed even at temperatures higher than the reaction temperature of 325 °C. Therefore, during the reaction at 325 °C, the acid and base sites on the Sc2O3 surface are poisoned in the presence of NH3 and CO2, respectively. To clarify the functions of acid and base of the Sc2O3 catalyst, we examined the poisoning experiments using NH3 and CO2 carrier gases. Table 4 summarizes the average conversion in the catalytic activities with different poisoning gases at 325 °C, while Fig. S5 shows the changes in the conversion and the selectivity with TOS. The 2,3-BDO conversion was partially reduced in both CO2 and NH3 carrier gases. The 3B2OL selectivity significantly decreased in the CO2 carrier gas, while the selectivity in the NH3 carrier gas was close to the level in the N2 carrier gas. The fact that both the conversion and the 3B2OL selectivity significantly decreased with CO2 indicates that the poisoning effect of CO2 is higher than that of NH3. The basic site of the catalyst plays the most significant role in the formation of 3B2OL from 2,3-BDO, while the acid site also supports the dehydration of 2,3-BDO. It is suggested that the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to 3B2OL on the HT-Sc2O3 catalyst proceeds in a base-acid concerted reaction, in which the surface Sc3+ (acid site) trapped the OH group of 2,3-BDO and the surface O2− (basic site) withdrew the H at position 1 of 2,3-BDO, as previously reported [28]. The results of the poisoning experiment are consistent with those obtained for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to 3B2OL [28] and 1,4-BDO to 3-buten-1-ol over CaO/ZrO2 catalyst [49]. 3.6 Dehydration of 2,3-BDO to form BD over HT-Sc2O3 catalysts In the conversion of 2,3-BDO at 325 °C, HT-Sc2O3 showed the highest conversion and 3B2OL selectivity due to its high crystallinity and SA. PC-Sc2O3 and CM-Sc2O3 have lower activity than HT-Sc2O3, as presented in Table 1. Table 5 shows the comparison at 411 °C and a W/F = 0.94 h with 100% conversion. HT-Sc2O3 showed the highest BD yield and the order of BD yield was HT-Sc2O3 > PC-Sc2O3 > CM-Sc2O3. PC-Sc2O3 showed higher BD yield than CM-Sc2O3 due to the higher SA of PC-Sc2O3. The HT-Sc2O3 achieved a BD yield of 57.1%, which is comparable to the BD yield of 67% under the same conditions: in N2 flow at 411 °C and a W/F = 0.94 h [14]. Thus, we successfully prepared Sc2O3 with high crystallinity without a significant decrease in SA even after calcination at 800 °C (Table 2). Therefore, HT-Sc2O3 is advantageous for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to BD through 3B2OL due to its high crystallinity and SA. To achieve high BD yields, activity tests at different W/F were performed over HT-Sc2O3 at a high temperature of 411 °C (Fig. 9 ), where the numerical data are listed in Table S5. At 411 °C, the complete conversion of 2,3-BDO was attained regardless of the W/F. The BD yield increased with increasing W/F, and the 3B2OL yield decreased, suggesting that BD is obviously a secondary product obtained in the dehydration of 3B2OL. However, the MEK yield was almost constant when the W/F was changed. These results suggest that the dehydration to MEK is a concurrent reaction with the dehydration to 3B2OL and BD, and thus 3B2OL and MEK are primary products. At a W/F = 2.5 h, most of the 3B2OL were consumed, and a BD yield of 80.0% was achieved. We investigated the effect of reaction temperature over HT-Sc2O3–800 at a high space time, W/F = 2.5 h (Fig. 10 ). As the reaction temperature increased, the BD yield increased, while the 3B2OL yield decreased. The highest BD yield of 81.6% was achieved at 400 °C. At a reaction temperature of 411 °C or higher, 3B2OL was completely consumed, but the BD yield decreased slightly due to the increase in the yields of butenes and CO2. Fig. 11 shows the change in the BD yield with TOS in an extended run test over HT-Sc2O3–800 at different reaction temperatures and a W/F = 2.5 h, where the numerical data are listed in Table S6. At reaction temperatures lower than 400 °C, deactivation was observed in the early stages of 6 h, after which the stabilization of the activity. At 411 °C, the activity was stable for 10 h. Before the reaction, the color of the catalyst was white. After the reaction, the color was gray at all reaction temperatures, suggesting that the deactivation was caused by coke deposition. 3.7 Discussion on the active center for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO In the dehydration of 1,3-BDO, it has been reported that the most stable surface of Yb2Zr2O7 [34] and CeO2 [51,52] with a cubic fluorite-type structure is (111), and the oxygen defect point on the (111) surface acts as the active site. To explain the active site in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO, crystal models of cubic Sc2O3 are shown in Fig. 12 [41–43]. Since the most stable plane of bixbyite structures such as rare earth oxides and In2O3 is reported to be the (222) plane [32,38], the most stable plane of bixbyite Sc2O3 is also considered to be the (222) plane. Fig. 12a shows a cube of Sc2O3 with (100) planes, and Fig. 12b shows a cross-section of a (222) plane of the Sc2O3 cube. Fig. 12c illustrates the top view of the (222) plane of bixbyite Sc2O3, the upper three layers of the (222) plane shown in Fig. 12b. In a large (222) surface shown in Fig. 12d, six oxygen-vacancy clusters, which are composed of four oxygen vacancies gathered in three-rayed star-shape, are observed, and nine Sc3+ cations are regularly exposed on an oxygen-vacancy cluster (Fig. 12e), as surrounded by the large blue dotted circles in Fig. 12d. In Section 3.5, it is suggested that the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to 3B2OL over Sc2O3 catalyst proceeds by a base-acid concerted reaction in which the surface Sc3+ cations (acid sites) adsorb two OH groups of 2,3-BDO and the surface O2− (basic site) withdraws the position-1 H of 2,3-BDO (Scheme 2 a). The active site could be provided by the three-rayed star-shaped oxygen vacancies on the surface of Sc2O3 (Fig. 12d), on which two Sc3+ cations and a surface O2− were exposed (Fig. 12f). In yttrium zirconate, Y2Zr2O7, with a cubic fluorite structure, 1/8 of the oxygen-occupied sites on the surface are oxygen vacancies [39], but Y2Zr2O7 is not active in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to 3B2OL (Table 1). On the other hand, Sc2O3 and In2O3 with a bixbyite structure showed high activity in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO in this study. The increased activity over Sc2O3 is probably due to four oxygen vacancies in the form of a three-rayed star and a specific length between Sc3+ cations, facilitating the adsorption of 2,3-BDO on the exposed cation sites due to their spatial extent. Correlation between the ionic radius of cation in the oxide and the catalytic activity has been discussed in the dehydration of BDOs over rare earth oxides [9,53] and rare earth zirconate catalysts [39]. Therefore, we further discuss the correlation between the ionic radius and the catalytic activity on four rare earth oxides and In2O3 used in this study. Since the reaction is expected to be accelerated through the adsorption of the two OH groups of 2,3-BDO (Scheme 2a) on any of the three central cations (triangle in Fig. 12e) among nine exposed cations (Fig. 12e), the length between the central cations in the rare earth oxides and In2O3 (a1 in Fig. 12e) was determined by the VESTA modeling [41]. Table 6 summarizes the length in M-M (a1 in Fig. 12e) and M-O (b1 and b2 in Fig. 12f) of bixbyite-type oxides such as Sc2O3, In2O3, Yb2O3, Y2O3, and Dy2O3, where M is a metal cation. The M-M length varied from the smallest 3.76 Å in Sc2O3 to the largest 4.05 Å in Dy2O3. On the other hand, in an optimized model structure of meso-2,3-BDO (Fig. S1, as described in Section 2.2), the O-O length between the OH groups and the O-H length between the position-1 hydrogen and the position-2 OH group were determined to be 2.95 and 2.69 Å, respectively. The optimized O-O distance between OH groups in meso-2,3-BDO, 2.95 Å is smaller than the M-M lengths of the catalysts. The M-M length of 3.76 Å for Sc2O3 is the closest value to the O-O distance, 2.95 Å among the five oxides listed in Table 6. Sc2O3 and In2O3 with short M-M lengths could be well fitted to the optimized O-O distance of OH groups in meso-2,3-BDO, while Yb2O3, Y2O3, and Dy2O3 with long M-M lengths would be misfitted. We think that this could be the most crucial reason that Sc2O3 and In2O3 are only active for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO. Besides, the M-O length, b1 (shown in Fig. 12f), might be necessary for the adsorption of 2,3-BDO. The b1 length varied from 4.66 Å of Sc2O3 to 5.00 Å of Dy2O3, and the length should be fitted to the OH distance between the position-1 hydrogen and the position-2 OH group, 2.69 Å (Section 2.2 and Fig. S1). Even in Sc2O3, the b1 length of 4.66 Å would be long to fit with the OH distance of 2.69 Å in 2,3-BDO, but the b1 length of 5.00 Å in Dy2O3 is too long to create enough interaction between 2,3-BDO and Dy2O3 surface. In the actual reaction, the OO distance between the OH groups of 2,3-BDO can vary from the optimized value. In addition, the dehydration of 1,4-BDO can be effectively catalyzed by Yb2O3, Y2O3, and Dy2O3 rather than by Sc2O3 [37]. The OH distance between the position-2 hydrogen and the position-1 OH group of 1,4-BDO would be close to that of 2,3-BDO. Thus, the OH distance could be fitted to the M-O lengths in the range between 4.66 and 5.00 Å. Also, in the adsorption of 1,4-BDO with a flexible structure, the OO distance between the OH groups could be tunable to the M-M length. Therefore, we can conclude that cubic bixbyite Sc2O3 with the smallest M-M length as well as In2O3 with the second smallest one is the most active in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO and that the other rare earth oxides with the large M-M lengths are scarcely active (Table 6). This geometric consideration could explain that the well-crystallized bixbyite Sc2O3 has high activity in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO because the (222) plane, on which oxygen vacancies are arranged symmetrically, is the most stable plane. Oxygen-vacancy clusters with exposed Sc3+ cations on the surface would provide uniform active sites for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO, as shown in Fig. 12f. HT-Sc2O3 was highly crystallized so that the surface oxygen-deficient clusters are spread homogeneously on the surface, leading to high selectivity to a specific product, 3B2OL. Since the ionic radius of Sc is the smallest in the rare earth cations [9,12], the smallest Sc-Sc length in Sc2O3 among the rare earth oxides with a bixbyite structure is suggested to be the most favorable for the adsorption site of 2,3-BDO to activate the dehydration. There is an exception: In2O3 exhibits the highest formation rate of 3B2OL with a moderate selectivity (Table 6), indicating that the redox property of In2O3 may concern the activation of 2,3-BDO, as observed in the dehydration of 1,4-BDO over In2O3 [32] and 1,3-BDO over cubic fluorite CeO2 [38,54]. Finally, we discussed the formation of BD from 3B2OL. In the comparison of dehydration of 3B2OL with 2-butanol, 3B2OL had higher reactivity to form BD than 2-butanol to form butene isomers over Sc2O3 at 350 °C (Fig. S6), while both of the reactions were deactivated in the initial period for 5 h. This is harmonized with a recent report [55]: the reactivity of UOLs such as 3B2OL, 2-buten-1-ol, and 3-buten-1-ol is higher than that of saturated alcohols such as 1-butanol and 2-butanol in the dehydration of C4 monoalcohol over Y2Zr2O7. The C=C double bond of 3B2OL could have an attractive interaction with Sc3+ cation of Sc2O3 surface (Scheme 2b), thereby promoting the dehydration to BD. Because the strength of the interaction of 2,3-BDO with Sc3+ cation is higher than that between 3B2OL and Sc3+ cation, it is probable that the dehydration of 2,3-BDO proceeds stepwise: the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to 3B2OL proceeds preferentially at < 350 °C (Scheme 2a) and the following dehydration of 3B2OL to BD proceeds at > 350 °C (Scheme 2b) in Figs. 6 and 11. 4 Conclusions Vapor-phase catalytic dehydration of 2,3-BDO to form BD through 3B2OL was studied over Sc2O3 catalysts prepared through hydrothermal aging. Crystallization of ScOOH during HT aging significantly affected the catalytic activity of the resulting Sc2O3 catalysts in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO: the catalytic activity of HT-aged Sc2O3 was twice as high as that of non-hydrothermal samples and a commercial one irrespective of the specific surface areas. Calcination at 800 °C or higher is also efficient for the selective formation of 2,3-BDO to form 3B2OL. In the formation of BD from 2,3-BDO at 411 °C, Sc2O3 aged at 200 °C followed by the calcination at 800 °C showed excellent catalytic activity with the BD yield of 80%. The catalytic activity of Sc2O3 was reduced in acidic and basic carrier gases such as CO2 and NH3, and thus the dehydration of 2,3-BDO proceeds via a base-acid concerted mechanism over Sc2O3 catalysts. In a (222) plane model of bixbyite Sc2O3, it was concluded that oxygen-deficient clusters provided uniform active sites for the dehydration of 2,3-BDO to BD through 3B2OL in the vapor phase. The importance of the distance of Sc-Sc of the Sc2O3 surface was discussed on the activation of the 2,3-BDO molecule. The active sites for the dehydration were proposed to be a triangle of two Sc3+ and an O2− on the oxygen vacancy of Sc2O3. coredata.dc:description: Vapor-phase catalytic dehydration of 2,3-butanediol (2,3-BDO) to form 1,3-butadiene (BD) via 3-buten-2-ol (3B2OL) was studied over various single metal oxide catalysts. Among the catalysts, Sc2O3 prepared under hydrothermal (HT) conditions at 200 °C followed by 800 °C calcination showed the most excellent catalytic activity. The crystallization of precursor ScOOH during HT aging noticeably enhances the catalytic activity of the resulting Sc2O3 for the formation of 3B2OL in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO. The formation rate of 3B2OL from 2,3-BDO over the HT-aged Sc2O3 was twice as high as Sc2O3 without HT aging. Calcination temperatures of Sc2O3 are also important: calcination at 800 °C is efficient for the selective formation of 3B2OL from 2,3-BDO. The HT-aged Sc2O3 also showed an excellent catalytic activity for the formation of BD with the yield higher than 80% in the dehydration of 2,3-BDO at 411 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Dehydration of 2,3-butanediol to produce 1,3-butadiene over Sc2O3 catalyst prepared through hydrothermal aging
